definitions.definition: to make cloth, a carpet, a basket, etc. by crossing threads or narrow pieces of material across, over and under each other by hand or on a machine called a loom
definitions.sensetop: weave A from Bweave B into Aweave something togetherweave (something)

examples.text: The baskets are woven from strips of willow.
The strips of willow are woven into baskets.
threads woven together
Most spiders weave webs that are almost invisible.
She is skilled at spinning and weaving.
The carpet was specially woven to commemorate the 1 000th anniversary of the cathedral's foundation.
The threads are woven together.

definitions.definition: to make something by twisting flowers, pieces of wood, etc. together
definitions.sensetop: weave A (out of/from B)weave B (into A)

examples.text: She deftly wove the flowers into a garland.

definitions.definition: to move along by running and changing direction continuously to avoid things that are in your way

examples.text: She was weaving in and out of the traffic.
He hurried on, weaving through the crowd.
The road weaves through a range of hills.
He had to weave his way through the milling crowds.

definitions.definition: to put facts, events, details, etc. together to make a story or a closely connected whole

examples.text: to weave a narrative
The biography weaves together the various strands of Einstein's life.
Comedy and tragedy are inextricably woven into her fiction.
Hall skilfully weaves the historical research into a gripping narrative.
The author seamlessly weaves together the stories of three people's lives.
The whisky is inextricably woven into Scotland's history, customs and culture.
The author weaves the narrative around the detailed eyewitness accounts.

definitions.definition: to perform or behave in a way that is attractive or interesting, or that makes somebody behave in a particular way

examples.text: Will Hegerberg be able to weave her magic against Italy on Wednesday?

wordOrigin: verb senses 1, 2 and 4 Old English wefan, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek huphē ‘web’ and Sanskrit ūrṇavābhi ‘spider’, literally ‘wool-weaver’. The current noun sense dates from the late 19th cent. verb sense 3 late 16th cent.: probably from Old Norse veifa ‘to wave, brandish’.
